channel.title: Familiarize samples
channel.description: Hey everyone! Dirty Bubble here. Im having a difficult time finding a practical way to use and find samples. I love sampling in my music and use to just transfer to fl studio. Now my computer has finally died and I’d love to utilize the AUXY sample. I usually take sound clips off of you tube, convert to my iTunes, then import into my fruity loops. How can I find samples to import on AUXY? Is the best way just to record them myself?

item.title: Familiarize samples
item.dc:creator: GioMakyo
item.description:
Of course if you’re ripping off YouTube, even if you eventually convert, the actual sound quality of the file will still be crappy MP3 in most cases. It’s hard to recommend what process to take unless you give some idea of what sort of samples you’re looking to incorporate. Sampling off vinyl, CD, DVD, or even recording with a good mic are all possibilities. Ripping works too, but is generally better for samples that are not going to be a really major part of your track. It’s convenient, but you get better sound quality using other techniques.

Read full topic

item.title: Familiarize samples
item.dc:creator: Aqzi
item.description:
The easiest way is with a mac.
1 - download off YouTube
2 - edit in audacity (optional)
3 - go to iCloud drive, Auxy, samples.
4 - drop sample in folder.
5 - make uwustep.

Read full topic

item.description:
In a pinch yes, this will do too! And is free. Kind of a pain if you’re planning on working with multiple files though

item.title: Familiarize samples
item.dc:creator: iammane
item.description:
AudioShare is a must. AudioShare will do all the converting you need.

item.title: Familiarize samples
item.dc:creator: Peregrihn
item.description:
If you make a recording with your phone it is automatically in .m4a format. There are tons of free online file converters that can compress/uncompress audio

Read full topic

item.title: Familiarize samples
item.dc:creator: Arimyth
item.description:
A .wav is just an uncompressed audio file. Most DAWs / recording applications have the option to export in the .wav format.

I’d recommend the app “AudioShare” to trim .wav (or any other type of audio) files on your mobile device. It’s pretty much a must have for any sort of mobile workflow in my opinion and allows you to export the trimmed .wav directly to your iCloud Auxy samples folder.

Read full topic

item.description:
otherwise I have to import everything onto another program like fl studio, and then add and trim audio + effects.
